verses.text: Woe to the rebellious and defiled city, the one who oppresses!
verses.comment: This verse opens an oracle of judgment against Jerusalem, described as rebellious, defiled, and oppressive—a recurring theme in the prophets. The city is often a symbol for God's people as a whole.

verses.text: She listens to no voice; she accepts no correction. She does not trust in the LORD; she does not draw near to her God.
verses.comment: This highlights personal and corporate responsibility in listening to God, and the closeness God desires. The lack of trust and unwillingness to be corrected is connected to deep spiritual failure.

verses.text: Her officials within her are roaring lions; her judges are evening wolves that leave nothing for the morning.
verses.comment: The leaders, meant to protect and serve, instead prey upon the people. Consuming everything and leaving nothing symbolizes corruption and injustice.

verses.text: Her prophets are reckless, treacherous men; her priests profane what is holy, they do violence to the law.
verses.comment: Prophets and priests, supposed guardians of truth and worship, are instead complicit in corruption. The reference to priests and the law foreshadows the importance of rightly ordered worship and teaching.

verses.text: The LORD within her is righteous; He does no injustice. Morning by morning He renders His judgment; He never fails. Yet the unjust know no shame.
verses.comment: Despite human failure, God remains present and righteous, always dispensing justice. The theme of God's faithfulness, even when leaders fail, points to His ultimate plan to restore justice through His chosen one (see Isa. 11:1-4).

verses.text: I have cut off nations; their fortresses are ruined. I have made their streets desolate, with none passing by. Their cities are laid waste, without a man, without an inhabitant.
verses.comment: This is a warning by example: God has judged other nations for their wickedness, showing He is willing to judge His own people as well if they do not repent.

verses.text: I said, 'Surely you will fear Me; you will accept correction.' Then her dwelling would not be cut off according to all I have appointed against her. But all the more they were eager to make all their deeds corrupt.
verses.comment: God's longing is for repentance, providing ample warning and opportunity to avoid judgment. The theme of God’s discipline as an act of love is seen here and in Hebrews 12:6.

verses.text: Therefore, wait for Me, declares the LORD, for the day when I rise up for plunder. For My judgment is to gather the nations, to assemble kingdoms, to pour out on them My indignation, all My burning anger. For the whole earth will be consumed by the fire of My jealousy.
verses.comment: This has echoes of eschatological judgment seen in Revelation. The 'fire of My jealousy' symbolizes God’s zeal for what is holy, pure, and just.

verses.text: Then I will give to the peoples purified lips, that all of them may call on the name of the LORD, to serve Him with one accord.
verses.comment: A reversal of Babel (Genesis 11), pointing to a time when unity and pure worship will be restored among all peoples. See how this prefigures the gift of tongues at Pentecost (Acts 2), a sign of the Gospel gathering all nations into the one worship of God.

verses.text: From beyond the rivers of Ethiopia My worshipers, the daughter of My dispersed, will bring My offering.
verses.comment: A prophecy of people from distant lands joining in worship, a vision fulfilled in the universal call of the Gospel. This sets a pattern for the gathering of all God's people to one altar, anticipates the worldwide Church.

verses.text: On that day you shall not be put to shame because of all your deeds by which you have rebelled against Me; for then I will remove from your midst the proud, arrogant ones, and you shall no longer be haughty on My holy mountain.
verses.comment: Forgiveness and purification—God will take away the proud, leaving a people humble and pure. The mountain is a symbol for the place where God is truly worshiped.

verses.text: But I will leave in your midst a people humble and lowly. They shall take refuge in the name of the LORD, the remnant of Israel.
verses.comment: God always preserves a remnant, a humble and faithful people. This underlines the importance of humility and trust, often expressed through structured devotion and worship.

verses.text: They shall do no injustice and speak no lies, nor shall a deceitful tongue be found in their mouths. For they shall feed and lie down, and none shall make them afraid.
verses.comment: A picture of the restored people as pure, honest, and secure. Many find here an image of the ideal Church, holy and without deceit (see Revelation 14:5).

verses.text: Sing aloud, O daughter of Zion! Shout, O Israel! Be glad and rejoice with all your heart, O daughter of Jerusalem!
verses.comment: A call to joyful worship, anticipating the fulfillment of salvation. This verse is echoed in the New Testament's depiction of Christ entering Jerusalem (Matt. 21:5), pointing to Jesus as the king who brings peace.

verses.text: The LORD has taken away your judgments, He has turned away your enemies. The King of Israel, the LORD, is in your midst; you shall never again fear evil.
verses.comment: This is a promise of complete restoration through God’s presence. The king in their midst hints at God himself dwelling with his people, which in Christian understanding is ultimately fulfilled in the Incarnation (see John 1:14; Rev. 21:3).

verses.text: On that day it will be said to Jerusalem: 'Do not fear, Zion; let not your hands grow weak.'
verses.comment: Encouragement to persevere in faith and in action. The assurance is for the city as a sign of God’s faithful presence.

verses.text: The LORD your God is in your midst—a mighty one who saves. He will rejoice over you with gladness; He will quiet you with His love; He will exult over you with loud singing.
verses.comment: One of the most beautiful images of God’s love and joy over His people. Christian interpretation reads this as a foreshadowing of Jesus Christ, the divine bridegroom rejoicing in his Church (see Eph. 5:25-27).

verses.text: I will gather those who grieve for the appointed festivals—those who were away from you, to whom its reproach was a burden.
verses.comment: Those who mourned because they were separated from public worship will be gathered. This points to the importance of the liturgical life and the hope of true, restored worship.

verses.text: Behold, at that time I will deal with all who oppress you. I will save the lame and gather the outcast, and I will give them praise and renown in every land where they were put to shame.
verses.comment: A promise of vindication and exaltation for the humble and afflicted. God actively lifts up the downtrodden—Jesus echoes this in his beatitudes (Matt. 5:3-12).

verses.text: At that time I will bring you in; at the time when I gather you together. For I will give you a name and praise among all the peoples of the earth, when I restore your fortunes before your eyes, says the LORD.
verses.comment: Final restoration—God gathers, restores, and glorifies His people publicly. This universal vision points forward to the consummation of all things in Christ and the gathering of God’s people into one visible and holy Church.
